editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The damoiselle, or the new ordinary.
London, printed by T. R. for Richard Marriot, and Thomas Dring, and are to be sold at their shops in Fleetstreet, 1653.

lg.l: Our playmaker (For yet he won't be called
Author, or poet) nor beg to be installed
Sir laureate) has sent me out t'invite
Your fancies to a full and clean delight:
And bids me tell you, that though he be none
Of those, whose towering muses scale the throne
Of Kings, yet his familiar mirth's as good,
When 'tis by you approved and understood.
As if he had writ strong lines, and had the fate,
Of other fools for meddling with the state.
Readers and audients make good plays or books,
'Tis appetite makes dishes, 'tis not cooks.
But let me tell you, though you have the power,
To kill or save; they're tyrants that devour,
And princes that preserve: he does not aim,
So much at praise, as pardon; nor does claim
Laurel, but money; bays will buy no sack,
And honour fills no belly, clothes no back.
And therefore you may see his main intent
Is his own welfare, and your merriment.
Then often come, 'twill make us and him the wetter,
We'll drown the faults of this, in one that's better.

list.item: Brookeall, a gentleman, undone by vermin.

div.head: The damoiselle, or, the new ordinary.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ye have your money; full a thousand pound,
Sir Humphrey dryground.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: And you have my mortgage.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: All well and good; all well and good. But, now,
Sir Humphrey dryground, let me counsel you.
You have already spent a fair estate;
A goodly, great estate: I do not taunt,
Nor tax you for't.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Because its pumped into
The purses of such wretches as thyself.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: But give me leave, now, fairly to admonish
You, to a care, how you do part with this.
You spirited men call money dirt and mud.
I say it is the eel.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: And you the mud
That foster it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: It is an eel, I say,
In such sleek hands, as yours; from whence it glides —

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Into the mud, oft-times, from whence it came.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I know you do conceive me. Therefore, sir,
(As I before was saying) hold it fast.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: According to the ballad. [he sings.]

lg.l: Youth keep thy money fast,
And tie it in thy purse:
For that must be thine only friend,
For better and for worse.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: So so, I see it going already.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Ay, to thy comfort. This is the usurer's scripture;
And all that they pretend salvation by:
To give good admonition with their money;
Though, in their hearts they wish the quick subversion
Of all they deal with. This is all they plead
Against the curses of oppressed souls:
Did not I warn you? Did not I say, take heed?
And so, and so forth. I must thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Ver
sp.l: You say, you'll make a venture of this money.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Yes Mr. vermin, in a project, that —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Out upon projects. Fie fie, out out out.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I 'em confident shall set me out of debt,
With you and all the world; and reap, again,
All, that I formerly have sown, with profit.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sowed! There's a word! Prodigal waste is sowing.
We shall call shipwreck, shortly, sowing too.
Hark you sir Humphrey dryground, may not I
be privy to your project? Will you tell me,
If I guess on it?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: That I will in sooth.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Is 't not to drain the Goodwins? To be lord
Of all the treasure, buried in the sands there?
And have a million yearly, from the merchants
To clear the passage.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: You have had your blow.
No sir, my project is in the behalf
Of the poor gentleman, you overthrew
By the strong hand of law, bribes, and oppression;
Brookall: do you know him sir? whose state you sucked ▪
That wrought him to a poverty that cries
Your sinful covetise up to the height;
And renders you the monster of our time,
For avarice and cruelty.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No more of that.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: You should do well to add a sum, like this
To his relief: to wave the bitter curse
That will in time fall on you and your house.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O ho! I now remember, you have reason.
That Brookall had a sister, whom you vitiated
In your wild heat of blood, and then denied
Her promised marriage; turned her off with child
A dozen years since, and since that, never heard of ▪
Ha! is't not so? Pray, did you know her sir?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I wish I could redeem that ruthful fault,
By all expiatory means: but thy
Inhuman cruelty is inexpiable:
Unless (It comes from heaven into my heart
To move thee to't) thou takest a speedy course
To give him threefold restitution.
I'll put thee in the way. He has a son,
A hopeful youth, a student in the law,
If his poor father's want of means have not
declined his course: give him thy only daughter,
And make his fathers own inheritance
(By thee unrighteously usurped) her dowry;
And pray a blessing may go with it; and than
Thou mayst regain a Christian reputation,
Till age shall lead thee to a quiet grave.
Come, is't a match? Will you bestow your daughter
On Brookall's son, and make your way to heaven by't?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You have your money.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: And thou hast adders ears
To all such counsels.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If you break your day
I shall think of your counsel.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Farewell vermin. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And farewéll dryground.
This parcel of thy land, I'll keep from wetting:The mortgage.
'Tis not in thee to turn an acre of it
Into pure liquor, for a twelvemonth's day.
And break that day thy payment, and the sun
Sets not more sure, than all this land is mine.
My daughter! ha! Can't be in thought of man
To dream of such a match? A wretch, a beggar?
Within there! Where ▪ s my girl? What Ally? Ally? Enter Alice.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Here sir —

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: My blessing, and good morn: now hear me girl.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Now for a speech —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The care of children's such a startle-brain,
That had I more than one, I should run wild-cat,
(Than one I mean, to care for) that ▪ s thyself,
My sober discreet daughter. Note my care,
Piled up for thee in massy sums of wealth;
Too weighty for thy weak consideration
to guess from whence it came, or how together
So laid in mountainous heaps.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: It is indeed
As strange to me, as are the stony wonders
On Salisbury plain to others. But my duty
Persuades me 'twas your thrift, and that great blessing
That gives increase to honest industry,
Drawn on it by your prayers and upright life,
That wrought these heaps together.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O, Ally Ally,
'Tis well if thine with all thy housewifry
Can keep 'em so. I thank thee for thy judgement
And charitable thoughts. But —

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: You had other ways.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I say, thou art the only child I care for ▪
Thy brother (Though I loathe to call him so)
Is, now, an utter stranger to my blood;
Not to be named but with my curse, a wolf
That tears my very bowels out.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Your money.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: A riotous reprobate, that hath consumed
His last, already, of my means and blessing.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: But he yet may be turned sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Out oth' compter!
May he be so, dost think? Could I but dream
His creditors, that have him fast, could be
So idly merciful, or that his youthful ghing
Could stretch, to get him out, I'll lay, myself,
An action on him weightier, than the strength
Of all their poor abilities could lift:
His jacks, his Toms, his Nams, nolls, gills, and nuns,
The roaring fry of his blade-brandishing mates
Should not release his carcase: if they did,
I'd force him to a trial for his life,
For the two hundred pieces that he pilfered.
Out of my countinghouse. He shall up.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: I will not forfeit my obedience sir,
To urge against your justice, only I crave
Your leave to grieve, that I have such a brother.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Thou shalt defy the name of brother in him,
My only, only child; and but in one command
Obey me further, all my estate is thine,
'Tis that I called thee for.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: I do not crave
More, than your daily blessing; but desire
To know what you'll impose upon my duty.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Thou shalt, and style thyself a lady by't.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Now love defend me from the man I fear.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: This day I'll match thee to a matchless knight.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: The western kite sir, that was here last term?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Even he, this day he comes to town.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Would I
Were out on't first. A matchless knight[aside.]
Indeed, and shall be matchless still for me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I like those blushes well: I read his welcome
Upon her cheeks.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Sir, I have heard, he has
But little land.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: But he has money girl
Enough to buy the best knights land, that is
A selling knight, in the West part of England.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: He's well in years.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: A lusty bachelor of two and fifty,
With, oh, the husbandry that's in him.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: How came he by his knighthood? Cost it nothing?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No: he was one oth' cobbe-knights in the throng,
When they were dubbed in clusters. Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir, the knight,
that you expect this day, is come to town.
His man has brought's portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Fetch the man.
The welcom'st man alive is come to town.
Ally, my girl, my daughter, lady bride!
What title shall I give thee? Now bestir you,
I know his thrift, he has rid hard today
To save his dinnerEnter what disguised like a country servingman.
Welcome honest friend.
And how does the right worshipful sir Amphilus?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: My master is in health sir, praised be Go —
A little weary, or so, as I am of my carriage,
Which I must not lay down, but in the hands
Of your own worship.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: 'Tis of weight and locked: I guess the worth;
And warrant him the safety under these keys.
But where's thy master?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: At his inn in Holborn
Telling a little with the host, till I
Bring word from you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No, I will run to him
Myself: you shall stay here. his chamber
Fitted against he comes, Ally, bestir you,
And think no pains your trouble on this day,
To morrows sun shall light your wedding way. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Unless some unexpected fate relieve me,
I shall be hurried to my endless ruin.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: You are sad, methinks , young mistress, I can tell you,
My master, when he comes, will make you merry.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: How? As he is a fool?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: No: but as he has
The soul of mirth and music at command;
Money, the all-rejoycing spirit, that
He'll make you merry with: not that alone,
but dignity, which women prize above money,
You are a lady by't: mark that. And if
He has a weakness, which you reckon folly;
It lays you open way to sovereignty;
The thing which is of most esteem. You'll be
His lady regent; rule all his, and him.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: This fellow talks not like a servingman:
A forty shilling wages creature, but
Some disguised spokesman. What may be the trick on't?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: You cannot, in the state you are, imagine
What 'tis to be a wife to such a man.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: No more than you perceive the pains you lose
In fooling for him thus. But spare your breath,
And take this brief taste of his entertainment.
First know, that i do know the man you speak of,
To be a covetous miser; old and foolish.
Not worth in my estimation the worst meal
That ever he himself paid three pence for.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Who do you mean? Sir Amphilus my knight.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Yes squire, i know him and his qualities;
The ways he got his wealth by, casual matches;
Of forty, fifty, and sometimes a hundred
For one. When bounteous fortune (Seldom failing
Men of his brain) cast all into his mouth,
The gudgeon gap d for. And how slight a thing
It is, for such base worldlings to be rich?
That study nothing but to scrape and save.
That have no faith, but in their ready money,
Nor love to worldly pleasures above those
Poor cobbler's use.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Cheap whores, and duck-hunting:
There's his delight indeed.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: I hate to think of of such a dunghill scarab.
A water-dog knight!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: But wedlock, to his age, will bring him home
to choicer pleasures, and abandon such.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: His age is fit for nothing, but to rock
Another's child; and to rejoice through spectacles,
At the strong guess he has, it is his own.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: You slight him strangely yet: but when you see
Him, and his weighty reasons to confute you. —

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: I will nor weigh, nor see him, or his reasons.
And if thou owest him so much service, tell him;
Go back and tell him straight: save him the end
Of his intended journey. For to come
Hither, will be to drive me hence. And tell
My father, ere he shall enforce me, take him;
I'll fly into the arms of one he hates.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Yes, by all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: These are the arms that must receive thee then.
Nay, be not frighted sister; look, 'tis J. Off his beard, etc.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Beshrew me but i am. How got you hither?
Could not the compter hold you?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: So it seems,
My virtue was not to be so obscured.
Noble sir Humphrey dryground, sister, was
My frank infranchiser. O, i have wonders
To tell thee sister. Thou must go with me.
But first, lend me some money. Borrow some;
(And let it be a good sum) of my father,
Now in his absence. Come, supply, supply
My pockets and thine own. For we must hence.
Thou'rt made for ever, sister. Quick, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: What's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: 'Twill be too long to tell it here.
The rascal fool, to whom my father gives thee,
Is come to town: and should he now surprise thee,
Here in my father's power, thy strength might fail thee.
Be therefore at a sure guard, oh, sir Humphrey,
How are my sister and myself bound to thee,
That plottest this escape. Dispatch good Ally,
And hear thee rest by th' way.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Why? Whither? What ▪ s the matter?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Say thou will have that coxcomb, I'll but kill thee,
And leave the here: and all my care is over.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: I'll sooner die then have him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Why do you not shun him then? O, sweet sir Humphrey,
Is thy care slighted thus, in my delivery?
In my disguise? In sending out my father
On tom-fooles errant? While a coach is sent
To the backdoor here; all to save my sister,
My thankless sister here, from worse than rape.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Why, whither would you have me?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: But hard-by.
But till the wildfire of my father's passion
Shall be run out. Slid, i had e'en forgotten.
Bear money with us, sister; pretty store.
Who knows occasions? Let him keep in pawn
My rich portmanteau for it.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: There's some good stuff in 't.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: More than he ll thank me for. We'll talk i'th' coach
In, in, and furnish; and so through the garden,
And, whirr, we are gone. If we should be prevented;
By this good steel, if i but hear one knock,
I'll make sure work o' thee. I can but truss for't .
There's a fair end on's both. And what will he
Do with his money then? Look how thou standst.
If you respect your father, or the dog-master,
To be your husband, better than me, then take
You your own course: mine shall be known next sessions.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Better then you, don't you respect your father
Better than me?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: No, if i do, let me be hanged for nothing:
and that would anger any man I think.
Slid, thou and i had one mother, (Which
We both take after) so had not he and we.
And he takes after nobody , that i know.
He loves a stranger better then's own child:
And that man's money, better than that man,
The devil above all i think. Thou dost not know
What coals we stand on.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Who shall look toth' house?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Wilt lose thyself with keeping that? Is that
All now? Away, away.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: You're a precious brother. —Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: All this needs not sir Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Do but hear patiently, and do your pleasure.
I go not about to stop your course, Mr. Bumpsey.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Nor i yours, sir Humphrey; nor your sons here; nor his wives there: only this gentlewoman, in mine own right i may be bold withal, while you depart my house, if you may be entreated, so. Is not this right? Is not this plain?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Yet hear his worship speak, good bump.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p:
Good whirly, what can his worship speak? Or your wisdom twattle for him, in this 〈…〉 i do not understand already? Has not his son wedded our daughter? How directly, or
indirectly, who meddles with his match? Nay more, has he not bedded her? How, directly or indirectly, who meddles with that either? Let him have and hold, possess (Hmh.) and enjoy; do his worst, and make his best of her, though she be an heir, i will not sue him out of her: no, i protest; were it ante copulam, as it is post, i would not cross 'em. Is not this right and plain enough.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: But good Mr. Bumpsey, brother Bumpsey, I would call you —

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Keep your brothers and your goods to yourself, sir, I have no need of 'em.
You are a knight, and a man of worship —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He will speak all himself.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: I am a plain fellow, and out of debt.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I, let him run on.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: I sought none of your alliance, i —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Has he the speed to run beyond himself?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes, and bring himself about, i warrant you.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Nor to be joined with houses of great sound,
Whose noise grows from their hollow emptiness.
I could have matched my daughter here, that was,
But now a baronetess in reversion,
To a substantial heir of two fair lordships.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Perhaps no gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Yet honourable, land-lordship's real honour,
Though in a tradesman son: when your fair titles
Are but the shadows of your ancestry;
And you walk in 'em, when your land is gone:
Like the pale ghosts of dead nobility.
Ha! is't not so? Is not this right and plain?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Yes like the privilege you use in your own house here.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Nay I come up to you now sir Humphrey dryground;
up in a point of chivalry. You are a knight,
A baronet to boot: your son is like
T'inherit that dear paid-for title, but
(You'll give me leave to use my plainness)

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Freely.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Your son (I say) is heir to your bought honour.
Which may hereafter ladify my daughter:
But where's the land you once were lord of? Ha!
The goodly Cornfields, meadows, woods, and pastures,
That must maintain the house, the gowns, the coach,
With all by compliments of horses, hawks, and hounds.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now he's in.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Where be the parks, the warrens, herds, and flocks?
Besides the gardens, orchards, walks, and fishponds?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: For that hear me.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Ods pity, give me leave,
You, that had all these once, in three fair lordships,
To be wrought on, and tonyed out of all,
But a small pittance of trois cents per annum,
By providence entailed upon the heir,
(Or thad had wasted too) which now maintains you,
In a proportion of smoke, and sack,
To wash your mouth with after, where you live
Confined in Milford lane, or fullers rends,
Or who knows where, it skills not —

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Must I hear this too.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Now he has almost done.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Can you (I say) think your good husbandry
A lawful precedent for your gamesome son
To make my daughter happy in a marriage,
Though he had twice my fortunes?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Now he's coming:
Bear but with this; and if he offer not
more than you would request, I'll lose your love

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: But here's the substance of't, you have my daughter,
Your son, sir, has my daughter, that must have,
And shall, my whole estate at my decease;
(No law exacts it sooner) this estate
You safely may suppose ten thousand pounds,
Which i have got by thrifty industry.
Only one thousand, i confess, my wife
Improved my fortune with, here's the just sum ▪
I give her leave to give it to her daughter:
She may endow her husband with it. So,
Is not this plain? Now note me further, sir;
What i have left is my own; and you, sir, may
Which what is theirs take hence your son and daughter,
Till you shall hear old Bumpsey is deceased.
Then let him come, and challenge all — that's left;
Mean time i know my course.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Now chop in with him, mother, you know how apt
He is to cross you in these moods.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dear, worthy, honoured, sir,

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Sh't, sh't, sh't; woman come you with me.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I bump. Let us go our way, and let them take theirs a-gods name.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pray hear me, sir.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: At this time, sir, he shall not.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Shall not! He shall sure: ods pity! shall not: are you pleased to speak, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not to offend —

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Not to a fiddlestick. Shall not! Can you speak or not?
If not, pray yell me so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I married, sir, your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: You may thank her mother for't, not me.
Well, will you speak?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I married her in a firm hope to win
Your love and favour.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Which, since I have not yet; and time must work it,
I would make this my suit.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Would I could hear it once.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That you would take
With reacceptance of this thousand pound
Your daughter and me into your family.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: And why the thousand pound; does't burn your fingers?
Give us but meat and lodging for t: my father,
Out of his little left estate will give us
A hundred yearly for other necessaries.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And as you find my regular life deserve
Your future favour, so extend your bounty,
When age shall call upon you to dispose
Of all your fair possessions.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Humh! A pretty odd speech this! I would I knew
The meaning on 't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I mean, sir, as I speak; that till you find
Strong probability in me to manage
A good estate, you trust me not with any.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Ha! is it so? Then i come to a point with you.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Mark him now, sir Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: You look, sir, in my daughter's right, to have,
After my death, my whole estate, by showing
Me, in my life time, your good husbandry, by husbanding of nothing:
Y' have ta'en off half my purpose; for i meant
To have kept it in my power, whether to leave her
Any, or nothing: and, perhaps (D'ye hear)
By an odd course, that i was thinking on
to ha' made all nothing ere i died: but now
Half of that power I'll put into your hands,
I'll try what you can do with something.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Half? What mean you half?

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Even half of all i have.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I hope you will not deal so.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: And as he deals with that, I'll use the rest.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Pray be advised.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Never by you 'gainst this:
I'll give him instantly the free possession
Of half i have: now mark; if you increase,
Or keep that half, then, doubtless, i shall do,
As well with tother for you: if you diminish
Or waste it all, I'll do the like with my part.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Husband.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: I'll do't: together we will live:
And I'll along with you in your own course,
And, as you play your game, you win or lose all:
Thrive and I'll thrive: spend you, and i will spend:
Save, and I'll save; scatter, and I'll scatter.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: You won't be mad.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: I'll do't: let him throw money
Into the Thames, make ducks and drakes with pieces,
I'll do the like: till he has made a match
Or no match of my daughter: there's the point
And the whole substance on't.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Will you do so?

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Will I? 'tis done. I'll make him a good husband,
Or be no husband for him: and so see
What's mine, out of the danger of his waste,
And have some sport too for my money: ha!
I love to do these things.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Nay, but in one thing, bump. let me advise you.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: In nothing gainst this course, good whirly: no,
'Tis so set down. I know I shall be counted
an odd old humorous coxcomb for't by some:
But the truth is, I love to do these things:
And so God gi' ye joy.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I'll take my leave sir.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Not so I hope, sir Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I have business,
And go well satisfied with this agreement:
And, Val. take briefly this my charge: you are now
A husband, be a good one: y' have my blessing.
But (Hark you) do you remember 'gainst the evening?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: All sir, all: I have spread my nets already.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: At your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I'll shortly visit you.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: At your own good time sir -Exit Drygr.
These shall stay here, I'll blindfold them with money,
And by a new way try, if they can grope
The right way into th' world. Come your way.

div.head: Act. ii. scene i.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And why this gullery to me, good Ambrose?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I swear i am serious, and you may may believe it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What, that there can be in the world an ass
(Wert thou a fool to credit it) that would keep
A house, by way of public ordinary,
For fashionable guests, and curious stomachs;
The daintiest palates, with rich wine and cheer;
And all for nothing, but all's paid and welcome?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Vall dryground told it me, whose truth deserves
So well my credit, that, prove you it false,
I'll pay all ordinaries and tavern reckonings
You shall be at this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I have heard
Of all the mockeries, the ape, the ram, the horns,
The goat, and such tame monsters, whom poor wits
Have sent wise tradesmen to, as to a knight,
A lord, or foreign prince; to be his mercer,
His tailor, sempster, milliner, or barber:
When those, that have been mocked , still sent their neighbours,
Till half the city have be fool-found. Ha!
Is't not some such poor trick?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Here comes my author. Enter Valentine.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: O Mr. bridegroom, that stole the wealthy match! How got you lose so soon? I thought you had been tied up by the loins, like a monkey to the bedpost, for a fortnight at the least. How does old Bumpsey, that Freecost drunkard, thy mad father-in-law, take thy stolen marriage? I am sure he knows on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He found's a-bed last night i'th' nick, as we say.
But we are pieced this morning.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Then he wrangled it out, of himself. I know his singular humour.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What has he gi'n thee?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Half, of all he has.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: On this condition, that, if i save
That half until he dies, the rest is mine too ▪

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What if thou spendst thy half?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He'll spend the tother; and the same way, he swears.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: He'll ne'er keep covenant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll tell you how he runs at waste already,
this morning the French tailor brought a gown home,
Of the fashion, for my wife. He bought one
Straight, ready made, for his old gentlewoman,
That never wore so rich in all her life.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: O brave old woman! How will she carry it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I spoke but of a coach, and he bespoke one.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Wonder upon wonder! Nam was telling one
Before thou cam'st.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What the new ordinary?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dost know the man that keeps it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They call him Osbright.
A brave old blade. He was the president
Of the can-quarrelling fraternity,
Now called the roaring brotherhood, thirty years since,
But now grown wondrous civil, free, and hospitable,
Having had something fallen to him, as it seems.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: That Osbright has been dead these many years.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It was given out so: but he lived beyond sea.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: There's some strange plot in't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O thou politic noll..

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Judge thyself, Val, what can the mystery be?
He tells me there's no gaming, so no cheating;
Nor any other by-way of expense,
By bawdry, or so, for privy profit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Such a suspicion were a sin. But now
I will unfold the riddle to you. This feasting
Has been but for three days, and for great persons,
That are invited, and to be prepared
To venture for a prize. This very night
There will be some great rifling for some jewel,
Or other rare commodity they say.
I cannot name't : 'tis twenty pound a man.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Is not that gaming prithee?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That's to come:
But, hitherto, nor dice, nor cards nor wench,
is seen ith' house, but his own only daughter ▪

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O! has he daughter there? Mark that Nam.
No gaming sayest thou? Ods me, and they play not
At the old game of old there, I dare —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I dare be sworn thou dost 'em wrong.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: She's too stale, is she?
'Tis above twenty years since he went over,
And was reported dead (They say) soon after,
In France, I take it: but, then, it seems, he lived ▪
And got this damsel there? Is she French born?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, she was born and bred there: and can speak
English but brokenly. But, for French behaviour,
She's a most complete damoiselle, and able
To give instructions to our courtliest dames.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: She must be seen.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: But see who here comes first. Enter Vermine. Servant.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Thou hast undone me villain.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Out alas!
I was as ignorant of the deceit,
As your own innocent worship ever was
Of cozening any man of land or living.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Was ever man so cursed in his children!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis the wretch vermin.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What makes he here, trow, in the temple walks?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What should he do elsewhere, when law's his lechery.
The devils itch dry up his marrow for't.
He undid a worthy gentleman I know.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Ay, Brookall, thrusting him out of his land.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He's fitted with an heir for't; one that can
Justly inherit nothing but the gallows.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Where's Brookall's son? He had a hopeful one;
And, at sixteen, a student here ith' temple.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Alas his fathers fall has ruined him.
Mere want of maintenance forced him to service,
In which he's lately travelled into France.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Go back to the recorders: fetch the warrant,
I'll search the city and the suburbs for her. Exit servant.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: But vermin has a daughter may prove good,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A good one like enough: I'll lay a wager
He's poaching among the trees here, for a broker,
To match his daughter to a landed husband.
This is their walk.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Let's try if we can fit him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou'lt ne'er endure his breath, it stinks of brimstone.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I'll take the wind of him: you are well met, sir.
They say you have a daughter you would match, sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: It may be I have; it may be not; how then?
What's that to you?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Pray be not angry sir.
The worst of us has land, and may deserve her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pray let me ask you first, if you be not
The knaves confederates that stole her from me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Is she stolen from you sir? In troth I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: 'Tis the first news we heard on't.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Though i assure you
We heard none ill today: but very good,
As that of the new ordinary. —

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Then the good success
This gentleman had lately with a wife —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And lastly, this you tell us; which, but that
It comes from your own mouth, were e'en too good
For our belief, methinks.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Pray, is it true sir?
That your daughter's gone, lost, or stolen, as you say?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: May we report it after you, good sir?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What are you? I would know.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Gentlemen, sir,
That cannot but rejoice at your affliction,
And therefore blameless, that desire to hear it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Cannot this place, where law is chiefly studied,
Relieve me with so much, as may revenge
Me on these scorners? How my slave stays too!
Yet I may find a time. —Exit:

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha ha ha. —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Look, look, what thing is this? —

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Trebasco, skip-kennel.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: It speaks, methinks.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Yes, and its shadow answers it in Cornish ▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know him; 'tis the wise western knight, that should
Have married vermins daughter.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Skipkennell, you shall turn footman, now, Skipkennell.
I'll ne'er keep horse more —

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: You must be footman than yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: No nor mare neither.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: You need not sir, now you be determined to marry, and live here i'the city altogether. And truly, sir, she could never ha' died better, nor been taken from you (As they say) in a better time, so near her journey's end.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: His mare's dead it seems.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p:
Was it well done of her, dost think, to die
today upon the way, when she had been i'my purse tomorrow in Smithfield: poor fool, I think she died for grief I would ha' sold her.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: 'Twas unlucky to refuse Reynold pengutlings money for her.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Would I had taken't now: and she had not died mine own, 'twould ne'er have grieved me.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Pray bear it sir, as they say — we are all mortal you know, and her time was come, we must think.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: An't had not been the first loss that ere I had in my life, I could ha' born it.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: And grace og (As they say) it shall not be the last.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I would thou couldst ascertain me that; but mischiefs are tailed to one another, and I must grieve as well for the what's to come, as the departed.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: We will have a bout with him: who is departed, sir?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: My mare, my mare sir: 'twas the prettiest
Tit — but she is gone —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How, is she gone sir?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: You will not talk to 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How is she gone, I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Sir, as it were, because she could go no further.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good angry man give us leave to talk with thy master.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Good sir, a little more of your mare.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: I would you had her all to do you good sir:
She lies but a quarter of a mile beyond Brainford.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Did you leave skin and shoes, and all behind sir?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Shoes all behind? I thought how wise you were: come away master. No, while she lived, she never wore but two behind sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Gramercy honest fellow, thou hast wit in thy anger.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Sirrah, answer not the gentleman so snappishly.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: How can I choose, when they do nothing but make a fool of your worship before your worship's face, and your worship perceives it not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good sir, fall from your man to your beast again.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: There again, another main mock: he would have him fall from a man to a beast.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Give me the shoes; let 'em go I say, I will have 'em.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Pray take 'em then, he'll never be wiser.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: These were her shoes gentlemen, I'll keep 'em for her sake, that little tit, my little poor Gonhelly, that would have carried me on this little iron from Pensans to s. columb on a day. And that's a way would try a stumbler you'll say, if you know it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, I know you sir Amphilus, and have fooled enough with you. Adieu; my business calls me. Gentlemen, will you meet me tonight at the ordinary ▪ —Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Yes, and perhaps, be there before you too ▪
Come Ambrose —Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Odd gentlemen, methinks

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Why did you talk with 'em?
What had you to make with'em ?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: True, we have other matters to think on: your first course Trebasco, after we come to our lodging, shall be to Turnbull-street, to the cobbler,

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Your dog-tutor.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes, and see how my whelp proves, I put to him last term.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: And know of him what gamesters came to the ponds now adays, and what good dogs.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: And ask him — dost thou hear? If he ha' not done away his own dog yet, blackswan with the white foot? If I can but purchase him, and my own whelp prove right, I will be Duke of the duckingpond.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Never misdoubt, your whelp's right I warrant you; for why, he could lap before he could well go: and at ten weeks old he could piss under leg.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: He was a fine forward puppy, true enough: but and that be a sign of short life, and he should peak away after my mare now — here, prithee take her shoes again: what should I keep 'em for? They put me too much in mind of mortality, do 'em away, make money of 'em, and I'll convert it into a dog-collar —

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: I'll try the market with 'em.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The frumping jacks are gone. —

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: See my aldermanicall father-in-law! How d'ye do sir? I am come. I keep my day you see before I am a citiner among you. How does my best beloved I pray, your daughter? You do not speak methinks.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ask you for my daughter? Let me ask you first what was your plot to put me in this fright, to make me trudge to your inn, whilst knave your man here. — is not this he?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I doubt sir he was taller.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Having first left a bag of trumpery with me,
stones, and old iron, steals away the baggage.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: This is abomination! What inn? and what old iron? I came at no inn today, nor touch old iron, but that with sorrow enough, my poor mare's shoes, she left me at her sad decease to Brainford. I had rather ha' lost the best part of five mark i wiss: from whence I came by water, landed here at the temple, to leave a letter to a kinsman's chamber, now right as sure as can be. Say Trebasco.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: He tells you true.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: But is your daughter gone?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Gone, gone.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: All ill go with her: did not I say I should hear of more mischief, and that one was ever tailed to another?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: You said so indeed: but if she had been tailed to your mare, I should have seen her sure, when I stripped her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: This is the day of my affliction,
This day I'll cross out of my almanac
For ever having any thing to do on't.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Why then, you will not seek her out today?
Although methinks the day might serve as well
To find her, as to lose her, if luck serve.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: What else did you intend sir by the warrant?
Best lose no time sir.
No, no, we'll go.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: First take my execration with thee, monster.

sp.speaker: Ver
sp.l: Hell vomits all her malice this day on me.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Hell sends by me this commendation to thee,
that thou hast there a most deserved possession,
That gapes to entertain thee.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Who's this, a conjurer that knows hell so?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: No, but a certain spirit, that my master
Conjured out of his land.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: If you can conjure,
Here's money to be got sir, but to tell us
What may be now betided of this man's daughter?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Himself, and his posterity must all
Sink avoidable to hell.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: You are most deeply read! May not a son-in-law —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Why talk you to that railer?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Pray sir, may not
A son-in-law escape in your opinion?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: No sir: it was by law he made the purchase.
And by his son-in-law, or outlawed, down he must:
If he set venturous foot, as his inheritor,
Upon the mould, was got by his oppression.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Pretty mad reason methinks; where's that
Land?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sirrah, I'll tame thy tongue ▪

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: No, wretch, thou canst not,
Nor fly out of the reach of my fell curses,
That freedom (Being all that thou hast left me)
Thou canst not rob me of.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I shall find means
Then to confine it, and yourself in bedlam.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Thou canst not be so just sure, to exchange
Thine own inheritance for mine.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Have you made
A purchase there too, father-law that should be?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: How am I tortured! I will fly this place.

div.stage: Enter Phillis, a box in her hand.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay prithee stay a little, good old man,
Give something to my box.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Out on thee baggage.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A little something, prithee; but a tester.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Out, out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou lookest like a good penny-father,
A little of thy money would so thrive here,
'Twould grow, by that I were ready for a husband,
Up to a pretty portion. Pray thee now —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What canst thou be?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Insooth a gentlewoman, but a byblow,
My father is a knight, but must be nameless.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Can knights get beggars?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why not? when such as thou get knights.
Nay, prithee, prithee now give me a tester.
I never ask less: my mother's a poor gentlewoman,
And has no means, but what comes through my fingers.
And this is all my work: come, wring it out.
O how I love a hard-bound money-master,
Whose countenance shows how loath he is to part with't!
It comes so sweetly from him, when it comes:
Nay, when? I pray thee when? Pish, make an end.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: It is the prettiest merry beggar.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Housewife I'll ha' you whipped.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I, when I beg i'th' streets.
I have allowance here, as well as any
Brokers, projectors, common bail, or bankrupts,
Panders, and cheaters of all sorts, that mix here
Amongst men of honour, worship, lands and money.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O rare beggar-wench! Lawyers and others pass over the stage as conferring by two and two.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I come not hither to entrap or cozen.
My work lies plain before me as my way.
With, will you give me? Prithee, hard old man.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What though thou comest to deal
For this man's land, or sell another's right,
Or else to match thy daughter, if thou hast one
To this young gentleman — thou wilt give me something.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The devil haunts me.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: She makes a youth of me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yet I prithee make not
Thy money such an idol, as to think
Thou shalt dishonour't, or impair this bargain,
That match, or whatsoever thou hast in traffic,
By parting with a silly silver sixpence.
Shalt not i'fecks la, shalt not; I'll strike luck to it,
Thy match shall thrive the better. Look, I have got
Here, four and sixpence, prithee make it a crown,
'Twill ne'er be missed in thy dear daughter's dowry,
If (As I said) thou hast one.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Hellish baggage!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He'll gi't me by and by. I prithee find
Thy money out the while. Come out with it man ▪

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pull her away,
I fly thee, as I would the devil that sent thee:

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Yes, let's away, 'tis time, she begs of me now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The devil is not surer to o'ertake thee. —Exeunt omnes preter Brookeall.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Good child I thank thee: thou hast somewhat eased
my pensive heart by his vexation:
She spoke as divination had inspired her
With knowledge of my wrongs, and his oppression,
To take my part: take thou a blessing fort
Who ere thou art, whilst I recalculate
The miseries of a distressed man,
Cast out of all. Unhappy chance of law!
More false and merciless than dice or strumpets;
That hast into thy hydra-throated maw
Gulped up my life's supportance; left me nothing;
Not means for one day's sustenance, for breath
To cry thy cruelty before my death.
That law, once called sacred, and ordained
For safety and relief to innocence,
Should live to be accursed in her succession,
And now be styled supportress of oppression;
Ruin of families, passed the bloody rage
Of rape or murder: all the crying sins
Negotiating for hell in her wild practice.

sp.speaker: At.
sp.p: A man I hope for my purpose, and save me a going to the church for one: will you make an oath sir?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: An oath? for what?

sp.speaker: At.
sp.p: For two shillings; and it be half a crown, my client shall not stand w'ye; the judge is at leisure, and the other of our bail is there already. Come, go along.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: I guess you some attorney: do you know me?

sp.speaker: At.
sp.l: No, nor any man we employ in these cases.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: He takes me for a common bail; a knight o'th post,
Thou art a villain, and crop-eared I doubt not:
what, dar'st thou say, thou seest upon me, that —

sp.speaker: At.
sp.l: I cry you mercy: I must up (I see)
To the old synagogue, there I shall be fitted —Exit.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Can I appear so wretched? or can grief
So soil the face of poverty, which is virtue,
To make it seem that monster perjury?
Rather let sorrow end me all at once,
Than virtue be misconstrued in my looks,
Which I will hide from such interpretation. He lies on his face.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.l: Alas he's sore afflicted, and my news,
I fear, will strike him dead; yet I must speak.
Sir, give not misery that advantage on you,
To make yourself the less, by shrinking under
The buffetings of fortune.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: I desired you
To seek my son. Have you found him at his chamber?
Or has not want of fatherly supplies
(Which heaven knows I am robbed of) thrust him out
Of commons, to the common world for succour?
Where is he, have you found him?

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.l: No, not him.
But I have found what may be comfort to you,
If you receive it like a man of courage.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: He's dead then, farewell my tender boy!

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.l: Indeed, sir, he's not dead.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Phew —

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.l: Pray, sir, hear me.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: You'll tell me, man ne'er dies; but changeth life,
and happily for a better. He is happiest
That goes the right way soonest: nature sent us
All naked hither; and all the goods we had
We only took on credit with the world.
And that the best of men are but mere borrowers:
Though some take longer day. Sir, i know all
Your arguments of consolation —

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.l: Indeed he is not dead; but lives —

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: In heaven.
I am the surer on't; for that he lived
Not to learn law enough, to — hush. No more.

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.l: Substantially he lives in flesh, as we do.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Speak that again.

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.l: A gentleman of the next chamber told me so.
Only, sir, this; if you can brook his absence
Without fear, or mistrust; then he is well.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: How thou playest with me!

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.l: He's gone to travel, sir. Here comes the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am sure he does not know me. If he could,
I were as sure this charity would be rejected.
So much i know his spirit. Is your name Brookeall, sir?

sp.speaker: Brook.
sp.l: My losses, wrongs, and sorrows, speak my name.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You had a son late of this house.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: And do not you infer by that he's dead?
Good, do not mock me, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If this be gold,
He lives and sent it to you; forty pieces?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Pray, sir, from whence, or where might he achieve
So great a sum? Not in this world, i fear ▪
A handsome possibility he had once,
Could i ha' kept it for him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He's in a way,
Now to a hopeful fortune. A noble gentleman,
Late gone to travel, taken with good affection
Towards your son, has taken him to his care:
And like a father, not a master, keeps him.
From whose free bounty he received this means.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Do you think the boy did well to send it me then:
When 'twas intended for his master's honour,
To fly in silks and feathers? 'tis not servant like
To wave a master's meaning so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I had a letter too;
Though most unhappily mislaid.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: What from my boy?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In his own hand.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Ha! — but mislaid, you say. Ha, ha, ha, —
What is the gentleman? Or whither travelled?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That's all i crave excuse for.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Keep your money.
If you can render me my son, I'll thank you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You speak not like a father: wanting means
Yourself for his advancement, would you bar him
The bounty of another's full ability?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: I speak more like a father, than a beggar:
Although no beggar poorer. And i fear,
I am no father: for i would not give
My son to gain a province, nor except
This coin to save my life: if he be lost,
Let me look nearer on you, sir.

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.l: I hope
he will accept the money. Poverty
Was ne'er so coy else.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: I cannot remember,
I ever saw this face: but i have seen
(Many years since) one, that it so resembles,
As i could spit defiance on't —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: And charge thee with the murder of my son

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pray, sir, collect yourself.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Your name is Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Right, sir.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Sir Humphrey Dryground's son:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Most true.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Even so thy father looked, when, at like years
He was my rival: for young man, I tell thee
Thou hadst a virtuous, well deserving mother.
He won her without loss of my known friendship:
But, since her death, you cannot but have heard,
He basely wronged my sister, and, in her,
Me, and my family: whored her, and cast her off,
On the appointed marriage day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O, sir.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: You cannot but have heard on't. Nay, it seems,
My boy has charged thee with't, before his years
Could warrant his ability in combat,
And so is fallen; or thou, not daring stand
Trial in such a cause, by treachery
Hast cut him off; and comest to make thy peace:
Presuming on my poverty, with money.
Worse than the base attorney's project this!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This is mere madness. In an act so foul,
As your wild fancy gathers this to be;
Who could escape the law?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: The law; ha, ha, ha.
Talk not to me of law, law's not my friend.
Law is a fatal to me, as your house.
I have enough of law; pray stand you off.
Will you, sir, furnish me, but with a sword;
And bring me to fit ground to end this difference?
Will you do so, and like a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What shall i do for pity? — now i have it.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Talk not to me of law. [he fenceth.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pray hear me, sir.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Now sir, your will before your end be brief.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You know me for a gentleman, though an enemy.
(I must speak in his phrase) and by that honour
A gentleman should keep sacred, two hours hence
I'll meet you in this place —

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Pray stand you off — to friendly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: From whence we'll walk —

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Silent, as nothing were —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As nothing were betwixt us — to some other fit ground, (As you propounded) where we'll end the difference.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: By the sword, no otherwise.
No whinnelling satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You shall see, sir.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Go set thy house in order. Here I'll meet thee,Exit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I shall repent me, sir, that ere I yielded,
In that fair noble way, if you express
Yourself in this regardless of my honour.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I like a whore, withal my heart, that talks
So like an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Can you expect
A chaste and constant wife of her, whom you
Have wrought to lewdness before marriage?
Or may I not as well deserve as well in bringing
A maidenhead into your marriage-bed,
As a polluted body?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Here's a coil,
For a poor bit aforehand! Is it so?
'Heart, if a man bespeak a tavern feast
For next day dinner; and give earnest for't
To half the value, (As my faith and troth
I think, is somewhat towards your marriage payment
To be tomorrow) will not the hostess give him
A modicum o'er night to stay his stomach?
Your father comes: I'll whisper yet more reason.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Now pretty Mr. Alice, you see the end
I had upon you: all the scope thereof
Tending to your contentment. Are you pleased?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: So well, that could I but shake off the fear
(Which is most dangerous) of a father's curse,
I durst pronounce; nay, boast my happiness,
To be above my virgin hopes, or wishes.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Let your fear vanish then: and, if this night,
The happiness you are ambitious of,
Together with your father's leave and blessing
Crown not your bed, let all the infamy
Due to all perjured wretches, that have wronged
Beauty and chastity be branded here.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: The fair respect I have, sir, to your noblesse ▪
For what you have already shown me, bars
Mine ears 'gainst protestation. I dare trust you.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: As I have trusted you with my whole project,
My discreet Alice, further than I dare trust
My instrument your brother; though he thinks
He understands it all. Yonder he is,
Profoundly love-struck too, I make no doubt.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Fie! Can you be so lewd? Is that your reason?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Yes; can the parish parson give you better?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: His parish bull's as civil.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Well no more.
I'll talk with your father about it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I with your sister, and to better purpose.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Now Wat, what think you of my course, and habit?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: As I love mischief, and desire to live by't;
It is the daintiest course. — oh, brave sir Humphrey,
How I am taken with your shape! Old Osbright,
The father of the swindgers; so much talked on
Could ne'er ha' born it up so. Nor his daughter,
That was French born indeed, could ere have clipped,
And frenchified our English better, than
She counterfeits to coxcombs that do court her:
With her fine fee-fees, and her laisse-moys;
her prea-awayes; intrat a you make a me blusha.
O, I am tickled with it.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: A, ha, my lad.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Slid I could dote upon you. Had I been
Your son now, how I could have honoured you!
Though I had kept a precept by t, I care not.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Notable reprobate.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: The devil sure
Ought me a mischief, when he enabled that
Old wretch, my father to beget me. O,
'Tis in my bones; I feel it in my youth:
I know from whence the pocks is now descended.
The gout begets it. There's no usurer's son,
But's born with an hereditary spice on't.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Had I raked limbo, as I did the compter,
I were not better fitted with a copesmate.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: 'Slight, I could ask you blessing.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: And I think,
That courtesy you have seldom done your father.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Ne'er since I grew to any understanding:
Nor (As I know) before, but whipped and held to't.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Well Wat. You see how far I have trusted you,
To have the second hand in our great work;
Our project here. Though you must seem my servant,
You are like to have the better share, if you agree.
Upon the match, and make yourself my son.
How like you your new mistress, sir, my daughter ▪
The maidenhead here, the new ordinary —
The damoiselle, or what you please to call her?
What is't a match Wat? Condescendeth she?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: No man shall be her husband, but myself;
Who ere she lies withal, before or after.
That she has roundly promised. But she balks,
And boggles with me in a less request.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: She shall deny thee nothing. What is't Wat?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: You may command her duty, if you please.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: What is it man?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: 'Troth, sir, but one night's knowledge
Of her aforehand. One word of your mouth,
I know would do it, sir.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: O devilish rascal,
That can imagine this a father's office!
Patience good Wat.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: But that I am afeard
My father would be pleased with't, I'd take home
My sister else, and presently.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: In maids about your work. And hear you frank
Discharge the butchers, and the chandler's bills.
They wait below. The baker and the brewer,
I have made even with.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And the vintner too.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: The bottleman too, and tobacco merchant.
Do as I bid you, go. Now Wat observe me:
As an ingenious critic would observe
The first scene of a comedy, for fear
He lose the plot.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I do observe you, sir.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I have, you know, released from your thralldom.
Upon condition you should steal your sister,
To be at my dispose. You have performed it:

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Honestly, sir.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Yes ▪ honestly, as you say.
And though it be for her own absolute good;
Yet was your act so grateful to me, that
I promised you my daughter.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Right sir, on.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I shall be brief: you know my fortune, what
are sunk, and you have heard, I make no doubt,
'Mongst other of my follies, of a child
I got on Brookealls sister, on the by, wat.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: And this is she, I love a bastard naturally,
Ah thy are bouncing spirits: now I love her
More than I did sir.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: You come fairly on.
But now, my poverty affords no portion.
Now, Wat, to raise a portion!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I, now, now.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Now I come to it, wat: i took this house,
And in this habit here, turned pimping host,
To make the most of her, and find a husband
To take her with all faults.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: That's I, that's I sir: this has music in't.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: You will be secret Wat.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: No dumb bawd like me.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Nay in a plot of villainy I dare trust thee.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: In troth you cannot think how much I love it;
How I am tickled with it! Good sir, on.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: This I have designed to put her off
(I mean her maidenhead) at such a rate
Shall purchase land.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: How, good sir Humphrey, how?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: She shall be rifled for.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: How! Rifled sir?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Yes, rifled Wat; the most at three fair throws,
With three fair dice, must win and wear her, Wat.
You'll take her with all faults?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Can you suspect me?
It is the rarest invention, if the gamesters
Be stiff and straight, that ever was projected!
What is't a man?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: But twenty pieces , boy.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I vow too little, less their number help us.
How many gamesters have you?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: A full hundred.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Two thousand pound! A merry portion,
And worth as many maidenheads in the sport
A man shall find in spending it ▪ methinks
I feel myself even flying with't already.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: What art thou thinking, what?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: That here may grow
A danger sir, the gamesters being so many.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Why, there's but one must use her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Phew, for that
I were indifferent, if 'twere all or more
(As it is possible a wench might bear it)
If they come single, and in civil sort,
Allow her breathing-whiles —

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Here's a ripe rascal!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: But my doubt is, that such a multitude
May fly into combustion, blow up all
The business and our hopes.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Now your doubt
Reflects upon my judgement: didst thou note
How quietly those gallants here today
Parted with their gold?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Yes, very gallantly.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: They shall agree as well for the commodity,
As I have cast it, Wat; so well my boy,
That no distaste shall be or taken, or given,
Anon you'll see.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: She knows not on't you say,

sp.speaker: Dry ▪
sp.l: Nor shall she Wat, till at the push I charge her
To be obedient in the undertaking.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: And that's a sweet obedience: I could kneel
before my wretched sire in such commands.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Anon I'll make't all plain to you. How now Frank?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: There are two gentlemen in the next room,
That by all means would speak with you: I have had
The foulest coil with one of 'em, that persuades
Himself you keep a bawdy-house, by somewhat
He gathered eavesdropping, by your discourse here,
While tother held me talking; who is civil,
And loves me with a modest fair affection.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Where is his sister, Alice?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Unseen I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Then let them enter. Whip into your disguise wat —Exit Fran.
And be at call.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Presto, anon, anon sir. Ex. Wat stands aside.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Did they eavesdrop me? I will eavesdrop too. —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Did not I tell thee't was a bawdy-house?

sp.speaker: Am
sp.l: I cannot think so yet: there is some other
Trick in it; the maid you see is very modest.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: That is the trick on it man, she must seem so.
Her father deals for her.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Fie! Can there be such fathers?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Yes, and such mothers too: the town's too full of 'em.
Come, she's a jugling whore I warrant thee,
For all her fee-fees, and her laisse-moys.
Pox of her counterfeit gibberish I'll make her speak
In plainer English, ere I ha' done with her.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I have enough. You are welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: He looks like such a blade. Are you the master here sir?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I am the man that's much rejoiced to see
Such sparkling spirits underneath this roof,
Where all you find is yours. Sirrah varlet.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Each syllable he speaks bewrays him.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Varlet I say.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Give me the compliment. Gallants,
Wilt please you taste your welcome in a cup,
The spirit of whose never dying liquor,
Speaks o'er the brim in this high language to you.
Full six and thirty times hath Luna waned
The strength she got in six and thirty growths
From Phoebus virtuous beams, into this juice,
To make it nectar for Phoebean wits.
'Tis this inspires their brains with fire divine,
By which to write high strains; and herein lurks,
The gift, one has to bounce up his own works.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Your meaning is good sack, and three years old.
To put you by your beverage and your bombast,
I will nor drink, nor talk of other thing,
But the choice thing of things, your daughter sir.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Thou shalt not woo my daughter, nor ne man for thy sake,Sing.
Unless thou come until her by her daddy naked.
Her mammy's gone to heaven sir. And I pray,
Let fathers poor breed daughters as they may.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Your care, no doubt, is great what will it hold?
The rifling sir, I mean. Is your number full?
May not a man put in sir for a chance?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: What do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: May not we
Come it adventurers? Here are twenty pieces.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I find you have overheard me. Call my daughter. Exit Wat.
Now I'll disclose a secret to you. But gentlemen,
As you love wit and mirth, censure me mildly.
I am a gentleman decayed in fortune.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And canst thou be so base to sell thy child
To lust and impudence?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Be not too rash.
My child's as dear in my respect, as you
Were ever to your father.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Devil thou liest —Draw.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Nay, hold, good Ambrose; you e'en now were angry
With me, that did oppose your fair construction
Of this good gentleman and his virtuous daughter.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: My ignorance wronged us both.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Good modest Ambrose,
What do you think of this discovery?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: You had discovered more, if his impatience
Had not prevented me: but now I am dumb to you
In all, but this. If you'll be pleased to sup here,
I shall afford you welcome. I have business. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What can we make of this?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I know what to do.
If city justice, grave authority
Protect it not, I'll surely spoil the sport.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Canst thou be so malicious, that, but now
Didst love this wench so dear, as to run her
Into the hazard of correction?
Stay: here she comes, and the pimp whiskin with her.
Do thou take him in hand. I'll handle her.
Now madam, twenty pound a man! Nay do not
Coy it too much? Your provident father left us,
To make ourselves more known to you; as your price
Is known to us already: look upon us.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray ye sir, have you been ever in France?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: In France? No surely, nor in doctors hands
Since I was placket high. Why ask you lady?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: For, if you could speak Fransh, I could the better
Find what you say. I can no understand
What 'tis you mean by price. What is that price,
If it be no Welsh gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I mean
The price of three throws for your maidenhead,
'Tis twenty pieces. If I win it (Hark you)
What will you give me out of your gross sum
To take it neatly off; and like an operator,
Put you to no pain?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Parle françoy monsieur, je vou prie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Thou art a handsome hypocrite: and this
Cunning becomes thee well. I'll kiss thee for't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fee fee monsieur. O fee! 'tis no good fashion,
For the young man and maid to no ting but kiss!

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis not so good indeed; nothing but kiss.
A little of tone with tother will do well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fee fee, you no understand. That gentleman,
Speaks he no Fransh?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Yes yes. He speaks no French.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He monsieur vou mocque de Moy.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Owie par ma foy.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ha monsieur vou parle francoy. Je svi 'Bien aisie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Easy! Yes yes, I think you would be easy
to one that knew but how to manage you,
For all the boast of your virginity.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Excuse me sir, I can no understand.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Methinks you should. Come prithee leave this fooling,
I know you can good English, if you list.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Indeed I can. But, in my best, and all
I cannot understand you sir, nor frame
An answer to your rudeness. When you know me
Better, you'll speak in better phrase, and then
'Tis like you may find better language from me:
Till when, pray give me leave to leave you sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Nay hark you lady, hark you (Still more mystical!)
Nay since you can speak English, I must talk w'ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: So you'll be civil.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Civil I swear, and private. They go aside.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Does she not know on't, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: No sir, no:
Not the least inkling of it: the old man
Carries it so discreetly.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Bless me heaven?
Discreetly sayest thou. To betray his child,
To sale of her virginity.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Yes, discreetly.
She dreams of no such business; such intent:
No more than the cud-chewing heifer knows
The butcher, that must knock her down i'faith.
O, 'twill be bravely carried! I myself
Knew nothing till this hour: though I saw
Money put in his hand by divers gallants:
Men of great place and worship; which I gather
Are to be of the riflers.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Prithee who?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: All must be nameless. There are lords among 'em.
And some of civil coat, that love to draw
New stakes at the old game, as well as they;
Truckle-breeched justices, and bustling lawyers,
That thrust in with their motions; muffled citizens;
Old money-masters some, that seek the purchase:
And merchant venturers that bid for the
Foreign commodity, as fair, as any.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Was ever such an outrage! Hark thee fellow —They aside.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, I have heard you with that patience
(And with no better) as the troubled pilot
Endures a tempest, or contrary winds:
Who, finding ne'ertheless his tackling sure,
His vessel tight, and sea-room round about him,
Plays with the waves, and vies his confidence
Above the blasts of fortune, till he wins
His way, through all her threatenings, to his port.
You may apply this.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And you may be plainer.
Is there not such a project for your maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It deserves no answer.
But to be rid of you, together with
The devil, that inflamed you to that question;
Know, that knew I of such a plot or project;
Or, that I had a father (As injuriously
You have suggested) could be so inhumane,
To prostitute my spotless virgin honour
To lust for salary, I would as sure prevent it,
As there is force in poison, cord, or steel,
At price of both our lives. Sir, I have said —Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: This wench amazes me. Could I believe now
There could be truth in woman, I could love her.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Well, I'll make one: meet me there two hours hence,
And fetch my twenty pieces.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I will not fail you. In the temple walks —Exit.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Where, if I fit you not —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Nam! What discovery?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: A villainy enough to blow the house up.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And I have found (I think) a virtue, that
Might save a city: but let's hence. We may
Confer our notes together by the way. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. iii. Scene ii.
div.stage: Bumpsey, Magdalen, Jane, all in brave clothes.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I know he is flown out, and I
Am prettily provided for like flight:
And if I do not pitch as high, and souse
As deep, as he, while there is game to fly at —
Five hundred pieces he took out you say?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And said he would venture't at the ordinary.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: That's he, that's he! Why this is excellent.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: This was your folly bump. He was content
To have walked moneyless you saw, but you
Would force him. At a word you did la 'Bump.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: I force him, ha?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Ay, at a word, you put it in his head,
And put the sword into the madman's hand,
As one would say.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Good Mrs. at-a-word.
Let not your fine French frippery, which I bought,
Turned oth' tailor's hands (As one would say)
Huffle you up to sovereignty: nor your coach,
Which I have but bespoke, whirl you away,
Before 'tis finished) from obedience.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Good lack fine gentleman, that wears the purchase
Of a pawned forfeiture. Must I not speak trow?

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Excellent Magdalen!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Sir, i will speak; and be allowed to speak.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: And speak allowed too; will you Magdalen?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I, at a word; since you have put me to't,
I will uphold the fashion; learn, and practise
Behaviour and carriage above my ''parel.
I at a word, i will la, that i will.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: This is most excellent! My old beast is
Infected with the fashions; fashion-sick!
Pray madam take your course, uphold your fashion:
And learn and practise carriage to your clothes:
I will maintain my humour, though all split by't. —

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Mr. Vermin desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: I'faith I will madam. —[exit with servant.]

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: My husband, mother,
Reports of a rare creature come to town,
Of a French breed; a damosel, that professeth
The teaching of court-carriage and behaviour:
The rarest he says —

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Can she teach the elder sort?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: All ages from six years to sixty six.
Unless they be indocible he says.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Indocible! What's that?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Stift i' the hams, I think.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Nay, then we'll to her.
I can yet bow my haunches, come and go
With them, as nimbly as the barren doe.
My gimboles don't complain for want of oil yet ▪
We'll have this madam; and we will be madames
ourselves, or it shall cost us each a crown
A month the teaching. In a month we may,
Practising but one hour in a day,
Be madames, may we not?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Yes, if we give our minds to't; and but steal
Fit times to practise.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: We'll find lecture times:
Or balk st. Antlins for't the while. But mum.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Do you wonder at my bravery? Look you here:
This is my wife; and this my daughter, sir.
You have lost yours, you say: perhaps for want
Of husty-lusties, and of gorgets gay.
Ha! is't not so?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The world's turned prodigal.
You do not well to mock me, when I come
For comfort and advise.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Shall I be plain w'ye;
My best advice is, since your daughters gone,
To turn your son after her. He lies not in
For much above a hundred pound. Pay it,
And let him take his course: if he be not
Got loose already. Then (Observe my counsel)
Spend you the rest of your estate yourself;
And save your heirs the sin. It is the course
I have in hand, and mean to follow it.
You like it not (It seems) but thus it is,
When men advise for nothing. Had your lawyer
Now for his fee, given counsel, might have damned you:
You would have thought it worth your gold, and followed it.
Will you go with me to an ordinary?
Venture five hundred or a thousand pieces,
To begin a new world with.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Mrs. Bumpsey, I take it you are she.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: An old ape has an old eye.
He knows me through all my cuts and slashes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: How long I pray, has my good friend your husband
Been thus distracted?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: But when I am perfect
In the quaint courtly carriages, that belong
Unto this habit: in which, I confess,
I am yet but raw; how will you know me then?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: She is as mad as he.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: How ladylike she talks!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Or, now my black bag's on, I hold a penny
You do not know me. Bogh-who am I now?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Most unrecoverably mad! young gentlewoman:
Nay, I entreat your favour for an answer?
As you can pity a wronged man's distress.
Give me what light you can of my lost daughter ▪
You have been inward always, and partook
The nearest of her counsels. Tell me fairly
I do beseech you in this gentle way.
Though I profess I have a strong presumption
Against your husband, and his young associates
I met today; and bore their mocks and taunts:
On which I have good ground for a strict course
To force 'em to examination.
Yet I entreat you see.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: The world is turned
Quite upside down: else I should wonder
How you could make requests, that 〈…〉
You have (Too much) by rapine and oh 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Do you upbraid me?

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: What's the matter Jane?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: The fox here learns to sing.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I'll fox him out oth' hole if he sing here.
Will no prey serve you but new married wives, fox?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Why do you abuse me thus?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I heard you, sir, with too much patience,
Abuse my husband with your foul suspicion.
Who is as clear, I know, from wronging you,
As your own son.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Your mocks are monstrous.
Were not he fast enough, I would resolve
No other friend had robbed me.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Is your son a friend? At a word, he's like you.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I pray, if my man ask for me, send him to me, by your master's leave. By your leave sir, I made bold to follow a father-in-law of mine that should have been, into your house here, with much ado to find it. Any good news sir yet? Have you heard of her? I cry these ladies mercy; though you may take me for a clown, i must not forget I am a knight, and give you the courtesy of my lips —

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: In the name of peasantry, what knight art thou,
If not the knight of the ploughshare?

sp.speaker: Mag.
