sp.p: A fine spoken, and a well-bred man, at a word: he called us ladies. To see what apparel can do! How long might I have trudged about in my old coats before i had been a lady? And then he would do us the courtesy to kiss us: sure, sure, as courtesy makes a knight, so clothes makes a lady.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: It seems she's lost then. All ill go with her.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: What old youth can this be?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Your warrant, perhaps, may find her though.
And i tell you what.
I ha' sent my man to lay the ducking ponds for her.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Do you think she would drown herself?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Who knows what toy might take her? Is she not a woman, as other flesh and blood is? I had another occasion to one that belongs to the ponds. I tell you as a friend, I had not sent else: come father-in-law that should have been; hang sorrow. You have had but one loss today. I have had two. I'll gi't you in rhyme.
sp.l: My mare and my mistress I lost on a day,
T'one of ▪ 'em died, and tother ran away.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: You are acquainted among the poets it seems, sir?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Truly but one that's a gamester amongst us at the ducking pond; a cobbler, but the neatest fellow at poetry, that ever was handicraftsman; and no scholar, to enable him by learning, to borrow of the ancients: yet he is a translator too. And he makes the sweetest posies for privy-houses.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: What a youth's this for a knight!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I'll tell ye ladies — oh Trebasco. Good news at last I hope.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: I can never find you anywhere , but jeered and laughed at, and are fooled, (As I have often told you) to your worship's face, and your worship perceives it not.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p:
To the point, man. How does my whelp? He
is grown a tall dog by this i hope: resolve me quickly.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Why, to put you out of your pain; your whelp's grown a tall dog.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Good

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: You said you would tell us, sir; what will you tell us?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: And a handsome dog.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Good again.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What a dog-trick's is this?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: And has learned, besides the main game, all the rare tricks and qualities his tutor could teach.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Will you not tell us, sir, about your poet?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Hang him, my dog's worth 'em all, in ready money.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I pray, sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I will not give his ears for the swolnst headful of wit among 'em.
Are not his ears finely curled Trebasco? Like his dam flapses.

sp.speaker: Tres
sp.l: Yes, and his coat all over, sir, they told me.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Told thee! Didst thou not see him? My heart misgives me.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: See him? No indeed, sir; but i pray bear it as well as you may:
And set not your heart too much upon transportable things.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: The dog is gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: Stolen from school, sir; and sold to a great monsieur,
And shipped away four days ago.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O my heart will break.

sp.speaker: J. a
sp.l: Do not faint knight; cheer up your heart with your muse.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: My vein is yet too dull; but I will offer at it.
Three losses I have had; gone, passed all help.
My mare, my mistress, and (Which grieves me most of all) my whelp.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: That line is long enough to reach him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I would it were else. — oh —

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Od's pity. Look you, sir, your son-in-law, that should ha' been, is in much passion too. But you'll be ruled by me, you say. And if i lead you not to comfort, never trust neighbour's counsel while you live. Is not this plain enough? My own case at this time is as dangerous as yours.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: That's all that comforts me.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Neighbourly said. I thank you. Come, sir, will you join with your father-in-law that should ha' been, and me in a cup of wine to order a design.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: There's a reckoning towards.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: It shall cost you nothing.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: To the next tavern then. Ladies adieu.
To part with such as you to some are crosses.
Yet I'll not put you down among my losses. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Daughter while they are gone, let us fall on our project.

sp.speaker: Ja:
sp.l: For courtly carriage and behaviour.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I long to see this French young schoolmistress.
The Damasin do you call her?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: The damoiselle, I'll wait on you. —Exit.

div.head: Act. iv. Scene i.
div.stage: A rabble of rude follows pulling in Wat after them, Valentine, Oliver, Ambrose, Phillis.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: You rogues, slaves, villains, will you murder me?

sp.speaker: Rabble
sp.l: To the pump with him: to the pump, to the pump.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Prithee beat off the curs.

sp.speaker: Rabble
sp.l: No, to the Thames, the Thames.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why do you use the man so? Is he not a christian ▪
Or is he not christened enough think you, that you would dip him?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Pray gentlemen forbear: it is thought fit,
Upon request made by a noble friend,
Favouring his person, not his quality;
That for this time the pandar be dismissed,
So all depart in peace.

sp.speaker: Rabble
sp.l: Away, away, let's go then.
1. A noble friend! Pox of his noble friendship.
He has spoiled our sport. O! how we would a soused him?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Now, Mr. hackneyman, if you have so much grace ▪
Render due thanks,

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I thank you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I thank you for him too.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: On both your knees; unless you hold it better
To kneel yet to the pump: which you had done,
My most officious pimp, had not his pity
Prevailed against our justice.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So, arise; enough, enough.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Troth 'tis a shame be should get off so easily;
Let him be yet but ducked, or showed the way
Over the garden wall into the Thames.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good Ambrose, be not so severe ▪ who knows
What need we may of him? We are all
Flesh and blood Ambrose.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou art a wag I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Are not you married?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Mass, 'twas so late, I had almost forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: No, 'tis so late you ha' not yet forgotten
Some office he has done you in his way.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Didst ever pimp for him? Protest by what thou feared most.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: No, as I hope to escape this gentleman's fury.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Go, get the hence, insufferable villain.
I could e'en kick thee into twenty pieces,[he kicks Wat.]
Soon, at his rifling.
Think whilst thou livest what 'tis to be pandar. —
A pandar, — Pandar — there's for your remembrance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Enough. Amb. this touch, and I have done — ▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Away

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray let him go, I'll school him[exeunt Wat Phillis.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This may work good upon the rascal, if he
Have but humanity, although no grace.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: We have discovered the great rifling Val.
We know the jewel now; the rich commodity.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And think you have done wondrous wisely; do you not?
To sneak before me thither. I know all
You have discovered; and how far you are
Mistaken in the old man and his daughter.
All shall be plain to you soon. Walk off a little.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: We'll leave you till anon we meet at the ordinary. [exit. Ol. Amb.]

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I protest, gentlemen, I have not drowned sorrow
With so much merry godown, these three half years.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: As with your part of three half pints of sack.
We had no more amongst us.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: How much was that a piece think you?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: It was enough to show his prodigality.
In over-wastfull cost. You were not wont
To be a boordsend-king; a pay-all in a tavern.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: But now I love to do these things.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Now if you could be drawn to the ducking ▪ pond,
To join your groat sometimes with me; or twopence ▪
There were a recreation indeed ▪
That peerless princely sport, that undoes no man:
Though cheating there; and rooking be as free
As there is square play at the ordinaries.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Well the point is: my swaggering son-in-law,
Appointed to be here among the trees.
My daughter told me so. Walk hereabout.
If he can give light of your light, he'd chide.
Well try what may be done. I'll but step up
Into ram-alley-sanctuary, to debtor,
That prays and watches there for a protection;
And presently return to you. —Exit.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Let it be so; slid the old angry man!
Enter Brookeall.he'll cross us if he see us walk this[exit Amp. Vermine.]

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: These walks afford to miserable man,
Undone by suits, leave, yet, to sit, or go,
Though in a ragged one; and look upon
The giants, that overthrew him: though they strut[lawyers and others pass over the stage.]
And are swollen bigger by his emptiness.
'Twas here, that we appointed, further meeting.
The two hours respited are almost run:
And he engaged his honour in such terms,
As I presume he'll come. Honour! From whence
Can he derive that princely attribute,
Whose father has descended to a villainy?
His house was noble though: and this young man
Had a right virtuous mother, whom I loved,
Entirely loved: and was in competition
For marriage with her; when high providence
Allotted her to him; who since her death,
Defamed my sister, and disgraced our house.
My quarrel is not good against his son
For that: but for my boy! His doubtful talk
Of him distracts me.

lg.l: See the vermin,
That hath devoured me living, his aspect
Adds to my passion such a bitterness,
That turns me all to gall. I must avoid him,Exit.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Introth father-in-law that should ha' ▪ been, or that
May be yet (Come, who knows what luck we may have,
Though the dancing planets have cut cross capers over
Our heads.) I like this old fellows humour of cheering up
The heart well! And would I were lost too, after my mare,
My dog and your daughter: if this warm sack has not
Kindled a desire in me to play the good fellow, so it might
Be of free cost, to drown these dry remembrances.

quote.l: See ▪ one of the jeerers. Is this he, that stole the marriage?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes, and perhaps my daughter too. His father's gone
Now, and I know not how to question him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Let me alone to question him. Did you see this gentleman's
Daughter, sir, my wife, that should have been?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Since when, sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Since she was stolen away, sir. It were good
You would let us have her again; and quickly too,
Ere she be worse for wearing, as we say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Old Brookall is not come yet.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Will you answer me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are a busy fool.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I am satisfied. He knows nothing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You lie, sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I think I do, you know nothing of her I mean, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You lie again, sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I think I do again, sir. Pray be not so terrible;
Examine him yourself, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Were his eyes basilisks; or did he bear
Upon his hellish countenance the faces
Of all the furies (That no doubt attend him)
I'll shun no place for him. Are they acquainted?
O most prodigious!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What do you know, sir, of my daughter, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That she has a wretch, a miserable caitiff
Unto her father.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: How is that? —[aside.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A villain that has scraped up by oppression
Law-strife and perjury, a dowry for her,
So mixed with curses, that it would consume
An Earls estate to match with it and her.
And leave him cursed in his posterity.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: How blessed was i to miss her!

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Can he speak thus to him? [aside.]

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Darest thou confront me thus?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Darest thou yet keep a groat of thine extorted wealth,
And seest what judgements fall one thee already?
Can all thy gold redeem thy good opinion,
to thine own son? And though thou wouldst no give
(In case he wanted it) to save his life,
A hangman's fee, much less a judge's thanks,
Or price of a lord's letter to reprieve him;
Yet may this son survive thee; and hourly he
Unto thy last hour, thine affliction be.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O happy condition of a bachelor!

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: I like this well in the young man ▪ —[aside.]

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: How can you say you know this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Prithee how can't be otherwise?
Hadst thou a virtuous child (As here and there,
Some mothers win a soul) it would be taken
Dead or alive from thee, unto thy grief too,
To scape the curse might come with a child's part
Of thine ill-got estate: that's thy daughter's case.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O —

sp.speaker: Brro.
sp.l: Brave young fellow!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But show me where an evil offspring has not
Survived to spurn the dust of such a father;
And lewdly waste in one or two descents
(Unto their own destruction) what was purchased
At price of souls departed?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Will you vouchsafe to leave me?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Pretty odd doctrine, this!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have not done wi'ye yet.
What corrupt lawyer, or usurious citizen,
Oppressing landlord, or unrighteous judge,
But leaves the world with horror? and their wealth,
(By rapine forced from the oppressed poor)
To heirs, that (Having turned their sires to th' devil)
Turn idiots, lunatics, prodigals, or strumpets?
All wanting either wit, or will, to save
Their fatal portions from the gulf of law.
Pride, riot, surfeits, dice, and luxury,
till beggary, or diseases turns them after?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Have you done yet?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A word or two for use; and so an end.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Not so: it must be amplified a little further.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Torment and death! Is he come? Let me go;

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Nay pray sir hear them; though you profit not;
I may perhaps. Methinks it edifies.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: You said, and you said well; his tainted wealth,
Got by corruption, kept by nigardise,
Must fly as ill, through luxury and riot:
I add, that they who get it so, shall leave it,
To run at the like waste, through their succession
Even to the world's end: 'tis not one age,
Though spent in prayers, can expiate the wrong
Such an estate was gotten by, though the estate
Be, to a doit, spent with it: but it shall
Fly like a fatal scourge, through hand to hand;
Through age to age, frighted by orphan's cries,
And widow's tears, the groans and lamentations,
Of oppressed prisoners, mingled with the curses
Of hunger-bitten labourers, whose very sweat
Thou robbest them of: this charming noise is up
Of many sad, some mad afflicted wretches,
Whose marrow thou hast sucked; and from whose bowels,
The nourishment was crushed that fed thee, and
That ravenous wolf, thy conscience.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I shall trounce you.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: What's here? Worrying of vermin?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: This noise, I say, of hideous cries and curses,
that follows thine estate, will not be laid
In thy dear life time; nor in theirs, the strangers,
That must be cursed with the division
Of it, when thou art gone: but, still, it shall
Pursue, to all succeeding times, all those,
That entertain least parcels of thy money,
When they shall find at best, it can but buy
Disgrace, diseases, overthrows at law,
And such dear punishments; until, at last,
All hands, affrighted with the touch of it,
Shall let it fall to earth; where it shall sink
And run into a vein of ore, shall reach —
To hell. And they, that shall, hereafter, dig it,
Hundreds of ages hence, must all compound
With the grand lord o'th soil, the devil, for't.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: So they make hot purchases!

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Now sir, you may instruct the usurer, to make use
Of all he has heard, while I avoid his sight;
Heaven knows I am sick on't: you forget me sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Fear not: I will not fail you.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: No: I'll deliver him the use of all.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O the variety of my vexation —

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: And all is this (As I advised before.)
Spend all your self, and save your heirs the sin;
The shame, the sorrows, and the punishments,
That are join-heritable with your wealth:
As very learnedly hath been related.
And there's the point, and the whole substance on't.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Bestow your substance so sir, if you like it.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: Sir, my condition runs another way.
To the same end perhaps; following my leader, here.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Your son in law? Trust me, a most fine man:
And, if his life be answerable to his doctrine,
'Tis like he'll lead you to a fair end of all.
Doubtless he is a fine young man indeed.
A proper teacher and an edifying.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: Come sir, lead on, I hear you are provided
Five hundred thick for this free nights adventure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I am sir, here it is.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: I am so too sir.
And here it is: and here it is, and here and there, and here it is.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O brave old man.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: I'll make one w'ye at your new ordinary,
They lay 'tis excellent.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For rarity and plenty,
There's no such pension in all this city.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: And all for nothing?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For less than kiss your hostess.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: And is there delicate wine too? I must thither.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The flower of France, and quintessence of Spain
Flow like a springtide through the house.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O rare!
And all for nothing?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: Hang nothing. Be it as 'twill,
I am for any thing; and as well provided,
As you, or any the best gamester there.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: I love to do these things. But first, pray tell me
Can you tell tale or tidings of his daughter here?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not of his daughter: but I heard his son
Was freed, this day, from prison.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: How, how, how?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Yonder he is, still, busy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'll among 'em. Walk you back a little,
And, get I any money, I'll lend thee some.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll tell you how. Some friend has paid his debt,
The action is discharged; and he's release d.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You practise my abuse. 'tis not in man,
To do me such a mischief.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Away girl.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou art as hard, as this dry crust, here, was.
But he is better minded now, I hope:
Now, old man I am sure thou art for me,
Thou cursedst me before, but now thou wilt
Bless me, I hope, and not without a cross
Of a fair silver sixpence.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Hence you harlot.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay look you, if I could afford it, think you
I'd make two words w'ye: 'tis but a sixpenny matter
Between us; why will you be so hard: 'tis but
So little less left among all thy children;
And I'll bate it them in their prayers for thee,
Though I be at the trouble, myself, to do it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, she begs prettily. I must give her something.
Here wench.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: What is it, i will see it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis a good shilling, and a vie; will you see't sir?

sp.speaker: Bam.
sp.l: Look you, 'tis covered.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Gentlemen, will you come in? will you vie it?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: No we deny it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You may revy it then, if you please. They come not in to bind it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you come in again sir?

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Sir, after you, an't be to my last sixpence.
I will keep covenant w'ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: A shilling more on that.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.l: Done sir: there 'tis.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why, these are lads of bounty! Have you any mind yet gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What, to be bankrupts?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Troth, thou wouldst fear as much, shouldst thou but break
Thy porridge Pipkin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Prithee what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nell, my mother calls me. I ne'er knew sire, nor godsire.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nell?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yes: and 'tis as bonny a beggar's name, as ever came from beyond Trent.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This girl, methinks, howe'er necessitated
Into this course, declares she has a spirit
Of no gross air: and i dare think her blood,
Although, perhaps, of some unlawful mixture,
Derived from noble veins. One may perceive
Much in her language, in her looks, and gesture,
That pleads, methinks, a duty above pity,
To take her from this way, wherein she wanders
So far from the intent of her creation.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: Your meaning is, you would buy her out of her calling.
Is it not so?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ten pieces i would give
Towards a new one for her.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: Here's ten more
To bind you quite from begging. Can you afford it?
If yes, accept it. And let's see your back.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I make no curtsies, nor send thanks that way.
No, I'll be forwards in them. May my thanks and prayers
Multiply years and blessings on your heads.
And when i beg again, may beadles take
Advantage on my back, and lash the skin off,
So heaven be ever with you —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Stay. Who would not have given this money? Gentlemen,
dost not move you to give a packing penny?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nor move you them for me. I should, now, fear
One of their ill-got pence, here mingled, would
Corrupt and overthrow my righteous fortune.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O villainous vixen.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Each minute of this day augments my torment,
Yet i have cooled it with some patience;
Attending sir your answer.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For your son.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have no son. I ask you for my daughter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Be this your penance for your misbeleife,
High you to the compter: if you find not there
Your son; meet me an hour hence at my fathers,
I'll tell you news of him; and he perhaps
May tell you of his sister. This deserves
A fee. Your absence pays it me. Go quickly,
We have some business: and your stay will but
Make the scene tedious.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: We'll go. Wil't please you?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Yes: we will off in rhyme. There is no doubt,
If Wats be not the compter, he is out.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: Now, what's the next vagary?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Only this sir.
You have played at small game with me. Now there is
A greater try all of my love and bounty,
Instantly to be made. A gentleman,
(I stay too long) an intimate friend's arrested,
But for two hundred pound on execution:
Will you join charity to fetch him off?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: I would 't had been thine own case two days since.
One of your fine companions, some poor shark?
Ha, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you be pleased to see him?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: I am half sick of this condition!
I do begin, not altogether, now,
To love these things so well methinks. Humh ha!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, if you go not cheerfully —

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: Yes: i go. Exeunt ambo.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Good child, thy tale is pitiful; yet it sorts
So with the fell condition of my fortune,
That i crave more of it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I came not to
Discourse of sorrow, but to bring you comfort:
Will you yet have a crown?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: I prithee keep
Thy money child; and forwards with thy story.
Thou saidst thy mother was a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'll give you reason. Since i can remember,
She never did a wrong, though suffered much;
Nor the least unjust thing: no, though her poverty
And care of me have pinched her very bowels,
She knew not how to seek another's good,
So much as by request. She never durst borrow,
For fear to come so near the danger of
A promise-breach: and, for base ends, to lie
She holds it sacrilege. I'faith she jerked
That humour out of me; for i was given
(I tell you as a friend) a little to't.
It came sure by the father. God forgive him.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Thou saidst, thou thoughtst, thy father was a knight.
How thinkst thou he could lie then, so abuse
A virgin of that goodness, as it seems
She, that by him became thy mother, was.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The devil, sure, was powerful with him, then.
Nor do you hear me say ▪ all gentlefolks
Are of one mind. Alas they could not live
One by another then.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Peace, stay a little:
How came thy mother to decline her spirit
So low, as thus to suffer thee to beg?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Virtue goes often wetshod, and is fain
To cobble itself up to hold out water
And cold necessity: but sure, the quality
Came to me by the father's side too: for
'Tis a more commendable, and courtly practice
To beg, then steal. He was perhaps, a courtier.
I rather would be robbed of all i have,
Then steal one farthing.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Thou say'st thy mother never would reveal
To thee, or any one, her birth, or fortune.
Answer me, prithee, how dost thou collect
Th' hadst such a father? Or that he has thus
Wronged thy poor mother, by not marrying her?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now you come to me indeed old man: how now,
What do you weep?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: The sharpness of the air
Strikes on mine eyes a little. Prithee say.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I first, as fain would know the hidden cause
That works this aptness in me, to discover
My mother and myself to you. I know not
How to look off o'you. Ifaith you weep.
I have heard some talk of natural instinct,
But know not what it is. Pray can you tell me?
Or any like reason, why i should
Thus dote, and hang about you? Or tell me this,
Have you not been of better fortune? Are not you
Some decayed knight? Be not ashamed, but tell me.
They cannot all be rich, there are so many.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: O my heart!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yea, are your conscience struck?
Have at you for a father then: and yet
Methinks you are more old in goodness, than
To be, so late, so wicked, as to wrong
A woman of her sweetness. Yet I'll try you.
Here is a long-kept paper. This is all
That ere I gathered of my mother's wrong,
And of my father's cruelty, and condition.
It seems this was his hand, and ruthful farewell,
He turned her off withal. See, if you know it.
More than a thousand times I have observed her
Weep o'er that paper; ever careful, though,
Her tears might not deface it. If by chance,
As when those tears prevented had her sight,
Some soft ones did on that hard sentence light,
Her lips took off the trespass of her eye;
And her hot sighs restored the paper dry.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: This comes so near a miracle; that my faith
I fear is staggering. How gottest, thou this paper?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I stole it from my mother, (And in troth
'Tis all that ere I stole) because she should not
Weep out her eyes upon't. I do not love,
Although I am a beggar, to lead blind folks.
Do you not find there, that he is a knight,
Though he subscribes no name? He tells her there,
And tauntingly, he knows she is more sorry
For the lost ladyship he promised her,
then for her maidenhead. Let me hear you read it.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Mine eyes, are now, too full indeed; I cannot.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Are you the man then, whom I must ask blessing?
If you be, speak. I'll have you to my mother,
Though, I dare swear, she had rather die, than you,
Or any of your race, or hers, should see her,
Whilst she has breath. Yet I will undertake
To prattle you both good friends.
And you shall have my mammy,
And she shall have her Nell (That's J.)
The man shall have his mare again,
And all shall be well. How do you?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Prithee forbear me good wench but a little.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have kept my time you see; and shall not fail
In any circumstance. Here are two swords,
Pray take your choice. I have bespoke a boat
Shall land us o'er the water, where you please;
Though, I protest, I yet would beg your love,
Next to my natural fathers.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: This I feared ,
And charged the plain way. But't shall not serve.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You took my part of late, against old vermin

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Prithee who would not? This is another case

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, if there be no remedy, pray accept
Your forty pounds. The money, sir, may stead you
For your escape, when you have taken my life.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Your money 'Would hang me, sir. Your life's not worth it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis your own money; sent you by your son.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: How know I that? Or that I have a son
By thee unmurdered.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I told you of a letter I had mislaid:
Look you. Do you know his hand?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: If it be not,
Much changed, and lately, here is that will match.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Was ever given gold so weighed, and tried?
What lawyer, nay, what judge would be so scrupulous?
No want corrupts good conscience: nor excess
Alleys in bad, the thirst of covetousness.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What do you think, sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I think you beg again, and would be whipped.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I fecks, I do not beg; but came to offer
This grieved old man some of my infinite fortune
Found in your lucky money: lucky indeed;
For I have found a father by't. I vow
I think my father. Is't not a fine old man?
I shall know more anon.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her money, sure,
Has made her mad: how do you find it, sir?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: My wonder now, is, how thou canst be son
Of such a father! Thou art honest sure.
Here is your sword, I will accept the money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then I shall live, and so may want the money.
Will you forbear it for a day or two?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Your sword again.
Now, I profess to you, I have present need on't,
And am as strict, sir, for my right, as I
Before was to decline it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pray, sir, take it;
And give me leave to beg your charitable
Construction of my father.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: How is that?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did you but know the care, the cost, and travel
He has been at a thousand ways, to find
your injured sister, to make good his fault,
If possibly he might —

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: O fie, oh fie!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Till all opinion gave her dead; and then
The means he has sought to do you offices
Against your knowledge. For he knew your spirit
Would not except of his benevolence. —

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Read that, and guess whose deed 'tis. Stand off girl.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yes forsooth father, I shall learn in time,
I'll call him father till he finds me another.
I know he could not shed those tears for nothing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But does she live, to whom this was directed?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Speak low: is that your father's hand?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Along with me then. Girl, lead you the way.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Anan forsooth father,

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Show us to your mother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Shall he go too? What will the neighbours think?
There's none but beggars all about us. Ods so,
There'll be a show indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No matter. Will you go?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, they will hale you to pieces.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you deny me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How shall I answer't to my mother? She
Never saw man, nor has been seen by man,
That i know, in my life.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No matter: will you on?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: I'll save thee blameless.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Troth I'll venture. —Exeunt oes.

div.head: Act. v. scene i.
div.stage: Frances, Magdalen, Jane, Alice. Wine on a table.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Tres bien venue madames.
You are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Good lack! And is it you, Mrs. Alice? Is't possible: are you come to learn carriage too? I will make bold with tother glass of wine. At a word, i like your French carriage the better, that it allows elder women to drink wine.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: They have no other drink, except water. And maids are allowed but that.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: And young wives (They say) wine with their water.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Mingle your glass, then, daughter. This for me. Your father has so sought you Mrs. Alice.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: My father has missed us too, by this time.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: But neither of 'em can dream French enough, to direct 'em hither, i warrant you. And does she learn the carriages very well, Madamsilly?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Madamoyselle, si vous playst.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What do ye cal't? I shall never hit it. ▪ how do you find your scholar?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O, she is very good. She learn very well.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p:
But how much carriage hath she learned? Hark
you Mrs. Alice. Have you not learned to carry a man? Has not a good husband stolen you hither?
I can think waggishly I tell you: and an old ape has an old eye. Go to.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: No such matter, Mrs. Bumpsey.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What is that you say?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I ask you how much carriage she has learned?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: She come but dis day; and she carry both the hands already.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: How say by that. Is't possible? Can she carry both her hands in one day?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, and before tomorrow, she shall carry the foot as well.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: It seems, then, you teach handling before footing in your French way.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You may learn dat of de little shield. De little shield you see will handle de ting, before it can set one foot to de ground. Come, let me see you make a reverence.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Reverence! What's that?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis dat you call a curtsy. Let me see you make curtsy.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Look you hear then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O fee, fee — dat is de gross English Douck, for de swagbuttock'd-wife of de peasant.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: How like you this then? There's a reverence I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fee, dat is worse. See how you carry de hands like de comedien dat act de shangling.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Shall I ever hit on't trow? I must take tother glass.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Take heed she does not take too much.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I hope she will not. But there's no crossing her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Let me see your hands.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: There they be. They have been a little too familiar with seacoal fires, and much other course housewifry, which i shall utterly abhor, and wash off, when i have learned to carry them courtly.
sp.l: But shall i ever do it, think you?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and all your other parts and members.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I may win my husband to love me courtly then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To love, and lie with you courtly.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: That's but seldom, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You shall know all de ways to win his love,
Or any man's, to multiply your honour. —

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I will so multiply then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Not only in your looks, your smiles and sweet caresses.
(Besides the help of painting) that adorn
The face; but with the motion of each lineament,
Of the whole frame of your well ordered body.
An eye, a lip, a finger shall not move;
A toe trip unregarded. But your gait
And your whole graceful presence shall attract,
(Beyond affection) admiration:
As I'll artifice you.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I'll be a nymph. Diana and her darlings, dear, dear, dear, etc. [sing.]
But may I paint, say you?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Oh most allowably; nay, commendably.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Tother glass for that.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Then for the art of dressing, setting forth head, face, neck, breast,; with which I will inspire you.
To cover, or discover any part —
Unto de best advantage.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: That is to say,
To hide shame, or show all: that's her meaning.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You shall have no defect perceived, no grace concealed.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I am for the naked neck and shoulders, then.
For (I tell you mistress) I have a white skin,
And a round straight neck: smooth and plump shoulders,
Free from French flea-bits, and never a wrinkle
Near 'em, though I say't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: T'has been suggested by invective men,
Women, to justify themselves that way,
Began that fashion. As one tother side,
The fashion of men's brow-locks was perhaps
Devised out of necessity, to hide
All il-graced forehead; or besprinkled with
The outward symptoms of some inward grief.
As, formerly the saffron-steeped linen,
By some great man found useful against vermin,
Was taken up for a fashionable wearing.
Some lord that was no niggard of his beauty,
Might bring up narrow brims to publish it.
Another, to obscure his, or perhaps
To hide defects thereof, might bring up broad ones.
As questionless, the straight, neat timbered leg,
First wore the trunks, and long silk-hole: as likely
The baker-knees, or some strange shamble shanks,
Begat the ancle-breeches.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Sure the men
Took that conceit from us. What woman shows
A leg, that's not a good one? —[she shows 'a swadled leg.]

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: These among men, are followed for the fashions,
That were invented for the better grace.
(As our attires) to set off limb, or face.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Good lack! What knowledge comes from foreign parts?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I prithee Wat, have patience for an hour.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Not for a minute, sir, I'll not be kicked,
And called base pandar for your baseness.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Nay, look you wat.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: And had almost been pumped,
And made a sport for watermen i'th' Thames.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: But hear me, wat.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I'll hear my father sooner. (Give me hence
My sister) were he a ravenous beast, a wolf,
I would obey him rather than trudge a foot
Further in your base way. Heart i am hipshot.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Now, would his bodies pains convert his soul,
'Twere a good work.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I am in desperate fear
O'th' mourning of the chine too with the kicks,
And hunches they o'ersaid me with. O base!
Without resistance. Give me hence my sister.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: But how was it my fault?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Was't not your project?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What may this mean?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: No harm i warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Nay, it shall out. Your base inhumane project,
To sell your daughter's maidenhead. (I care not
Who hears me, J.) And cunningly to make me
Your hackney-jade to fetch your chapmen in.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Where are we now?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: What did my husband mean to wish us hither?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Baseness! I cannot call it bad enough.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: You were as forward in it as myself,
And wooed me you might have her without all faults.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Mine eyes are opened now.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: But i believe,
They were almost beaten out first.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: And i vow
Ere i will marry so, I'll take a beggar,
And join in trade with her, though I get nothing
But — my name is vermin already, i
Thank a good father for't.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: A beggar-wenches breed would propagate
Your name most numerously.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Much better than your sale-ware, and more lasting.
I think i saw her today must be the woman,
Good madam polecat, the trim schoolmistress.
I'll make bold with your scholar. What! you have more.
I'll carry her and her virginity
Unto some fitter place of execution.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: You brought me hither, sir, and here I'll stay.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: What! in a bawdy-house?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: O dear! and is it so? What are we then?
sp.p: Is this your boun fashion? Is this the carriage of the body, that you would teach us? What, to be whores? We could learn that at home, and there were need, without your teaching,

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Mother; what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Mrs Bumpsey; pray fear no harm.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: O good lack! what will become of us? where are we now, Jane?
Betrayed! betrayed! Our honours are betrayed. O my poor bump. how will thou take this at my hands, though i carry them never so courtly?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l:
'Sfoot, she's in her Maudlin fit: all her wine
showers out in tears.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: O, o, o, —[she falls]

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Pray have her in. Look carefully to her,

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Ay, ay, I.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: In all to the next room. —Exeunt Fra. Jane leading out Magdalen.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Sir, she shall with me. I'll leave her where i found her.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Sir, no such matter.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: 'Sfoot, gentlewoman, must I kick you out of doors?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: No, nor depart yourself, but by authority.
I am provided for you. Friends come in. Enter two sergeants.
And do your office.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: We arrest you, sir ▪ nay, we shall rule you.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Why, this is well, and very hospitably done.
Would any man but an old bawd ha' done this?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Sir, i mistrusted your apostasy.
Since you revolt, i must recall my money;
Or lay you where i found you, as you threatened your sister here.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Baser, and baser still. Are you a knight?
A knight, a post-knight. A postilion,
That rides a fore-horse, o'er the ears in dirt,
Three fingers thick, is not so base. You varlets,
Do you arrest folks in a bawdy-house?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: We do not find it so; or, if it be,
The place may be as honest as our office.
Will you walk, sir?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Stay; let me consider,
if now my father (As some in like cases
Have done) would take a fine submission.
I could afford to kneel and whine, methinks,
Rather than back to my old ward again.
'Twill ne'er be handsome though.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The business gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: My lucky friend.
Sir, you relieved me lately. Could you now
But add another favour, it might teach
One, that ne'er learned to pray, to pray for you.
Do you not know me, sir? 'twas I you saved
Out of the temple suds.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hast thou been shaved since?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: No, sir, I was disguised.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Disguised!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Disguised in villainy, which I recant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who knows but he may prove an honest man?
Pray, sir, a word.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: We do not use to wait dry-fisted; nor dry throated.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I would you were as wet all over, as I was like to have been: or, as you are catchpoles, I would you had been but in those hands I escaped from.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: You have prevailed, sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sergeants you shall not out of the house. Here's for half an hour's attendance. Go into that room with your prisoner. You shall have wine, and smoke too.
sp.l: Be of good cheer friend; if thou canst be honest,
I can relieve thee: fear not.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Sir, get my father but to say as much,
And you shall be coheir with me. I vow you shall have half. [exeunt Wat, sergeants]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We'll talk anon. The youth appears converted.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: There was no other means to work it by,
But that I used; to urged him passed his nature.
He was so free in's villainy, that I
Giving the spurs, ran him beyond his speed;
Quite off his legs, and glad to be led home.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: His father comes on fairly: I have followed
All your instructions concerning him,
And my fantastic father 'Law. Both whom
Are hard at hand, with the wise western knight.
He too's content to go to the best ordinary,
While 'tis best cheap he says. Where are the women?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Your mother-in-law, after she had got
As much French carriage, as might serve to furnish
A petty court; is fallen into a fit,
To overthrow it all again.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The better.
But is the house clear, sir, of all your riflers?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: As I could wish; and well satisfied.
For, when they understood the honest end,
My project aimed at; which, by an oration
Well charged with virtuous sentences, I forced
Into the nobler breasts: they all recanted
The barbarous purpose; and as freely left
Their money for that charitable use,
To which I pre-intended it. The rest
Pursed theirs again. But yet I have collected
In this odd uncouth way, five hundred pounds,
That was laid down at stake for a virginity,
To make an honest stock for Frank.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis good.
I may fetch in my guests in the mean time
You may be pleased, sir, to peruse this baper. —Exit.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: How now! what's here? How might he come by this?
It is the scorn I sent my injured love;
My abused Elynor: the hand, that threw
Her from me. O, that at the price of it
I could receive her.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Sir, by your leave,
We come to sup wi'ye. Does your rifling hold?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: What, you are off o'the hooks, methinks.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: If there be no such thing, tell us the riddle?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: You shall know all, and briefly. Frank, come in. Enter Frank.
Now gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Let us salute her first. —Salute, then whisper ▪

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: She does not taste of sin. Fair chastity
Sits crowned upon her brow, with an aspect,
May beat down lust to hell, from whence it rose.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You profess nobly, sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I vow, and do not lie to you: if I find
Your father so inhumane, you against it:
We'll be your rescue, if forty able swordmen
Which we have, at the signal of a finger,
Planted in readiness, can fetch you off:
Do you approve?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes, and admire your goodness.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Now we are for you, sir:

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l:
Then hear the story; which your late impatience
would not permit.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: You speak not now
In that high phrase, or tone, as you did then. Enter Valentine. Bumpsey, Vermine, Amphilus, Brookall, Elynor, Phillis.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Stand here, unseen; and hear attentively.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I am a gentleman, that by foul misdeed
(Heaven, heaven I ask thee pardon) once did wrong
To an unfortunate family, by rejecting,
After affiance, and her love abused,
A gentlewoman —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You got with child, and then denied her marriage.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: 'Twas so.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Ay me!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No passion, gentle soul.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If this should prove my father now! —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Well sir, your gentlewoman!

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: She, on the discontent, (Poor hapless soul)
Now fourteen winters since though sadly burdened,
Fled, and no more is heard of: at the first
My wildness took no sense of this dear loss;
But drew me through the ways of careless pleasure,
By riotous expense, that mine estate
And credit ran at waste, and was nigh spent,
Until my trespass cried against my conscience
To render satisfaction: but in vain
We offer to the dead. My genius therefore
Prompts me to grateful deeds unto her blood ▪

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: What can this come to?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: She had a brother, that lost his estate
By law —

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Means he not me?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: To a corrupt oppressor —

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ha! how's that?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Was stripped out of the very coat he wore,
had nothing left him, but a son —

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What's all this to your daughter?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Even all that may be; (See) his son's my daughter. Discover Franc.
Now do you find my project gentlemen?
It has at charge of three days housekeeping
Put half a thousand pounds in's purse; besides
A fair pull for his father's land again:
For he has, by a lawful churchman, married
The daughter of his father's adversary.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Why, here are wonders!

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Bravely, nobly done

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: Come Mrs. Alice; and justify your act. Enter Alice

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My daughter, ha!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: My sweetheart, ho!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Your haes and ho's can not draw her from me, she is my wife.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: By what witchcraft?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: By stronger charms, than your art can dissolve. You know me now, sir — and my project, do you not? Discovers himself.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Amb. sir Humphrey dryground.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I am struck dumb with wonder.

sp.speaker: Elin.
sp.l: O 'tis he, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Alas she swoons, sir cheer you up this lady,
While I appease the rest. A word with you sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I will not be appeased.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: My love! my Elynor!

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p:
So, cheer her up sir Humphrey. To her again sir Humphrey; your son and mine in law has told me all your story, and reconciled your brother Brookall to you before your interview. I know all, the full point and the whole substance; the flat and plain of the business; and now I love these things again. How now sir Amphilus
drowned in melancholy?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No: but and I were at the Duckingpond, I know what I know. But when I drown myself, I'll give you leave to hang me.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Your pardon, and your blessing, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Hence. Exit Valentine.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Was this thy journey into France my boy?
High providence hath made it good. But tell me,
Was love your chief instructor to this marriage?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Indeed it was equal in her and me.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: Pray sir your blessing.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.l: Turn this way for a blessing then my daughter,

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Shall I tell you neighbour? Law has no relief for you; and conscience and you have a long time been strangers. Could you be friends and embrace conscience now, all would be well. And there's the substance. Is it plain?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Conscience! do you know where she is?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Here's one has brought her in his true conversion.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Sir, if you can forgive, and can obey you —
I now can better kneel, then speakHe weeps

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you note those tears, sir? Had you lost your daughter,
My father had in this made you amends,
In finding you a son. His art converted him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Sure, all's but apparition, or a dream.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Ha! think you so? 'tis your own flesh and blood: and by your leave and liking, may prove as honest a man, as his father. Is not this plain now? Forgive and bless 'em all over, and so kiss 'em too. They are your children.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: O my dear bump! Art thou there? Thou mayst kiss, and forgive me all over too, for any harm, or dishonesty; though the place be as they say-at a word, bump. Thou mayst believe me, I came but to learn carriage of the body, nor to carry nobody's body, but my own body, bump. No truly, truly bump. O — oh — that ever I did that.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: Peace, peace: all's well. At least I know your disease.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Think me not drunk, good bump, a little fashion-sick, or so.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Fashion-sick! A fine civil word. To be drunk, is fashion-sick.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I am awaked out of the lethargy
Of avarice: blessed may our friendship be.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I will not sleep, before the holy priest
Has done the office. Blessing on my girl.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.l: Thou hast made me young again: the best
Occurrents in this project have been thine.
Thy accidents exceeded my design.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They do not yet cease here: for see, the strife
Betwixt these long continued adversaries
Perfectly reconciled; and both have given
The young and hopeful married pair their blessings.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: To which I have given my consent most freely.
For it was nolens volens as they say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They are beholden to you. Mr. vermin
Restores unto the son the father's land,
For dowry with his daughter: and is taken
So with the good you wrought upon his son,
The convertite here; that if he stand firm
Till 'The determination of your mortgage,
He'll cancel it, and send it gratis to you.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: That's sure enough. But sir, the other business.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The most to be admired of all;
He loves my sister here; and has done long:
But, now, that he perceives her worth (Being yours)
And, since you promised him your daughter too,
He makes it his fair suit.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: I'll talk with his father.
And what stand you but firm, and live reformed,
Winning my daughter's love, you shall have mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That fortune is not blind, that showed me way
To father, friends, and husband in one day.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: This binds us all into a brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: And with a brother's love I now salute you.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.l: So may we with a general embrace,
Create the heart of friendship, not the face.
Come gentlemen, your ordinary stays,
'Twill prove good fare (I hope) though no rich feast;
And acceptable to each welcome guest.

lg.l: No way ambitious yet of vulgar praise,
The writer of these scenes desires to know,
By your fair leave, though he assume no bays,
Whether he pulled fair for a leaf or no ▪
If yes, then let your hands assistant be,
T'encourage him to climb Apollo's tree.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
